title: Synthetic Recap
body:
In an era of defensive grit, one man delivered an offensive spectacle for the ages. Glenn Rice didn’t just lead the Charlotte Hornets to a 93-85 road victory over the Detroit Pistons; he authored a performance so dominant it felt like a fever dream, pouring in a career-high 47 points.

From the opening tip, Rice was a man possessed. The Pistons, known for their physical brand of basketball, had no answer for his silky-smooth jumper and explosive drives. He was a symphony of scoring, a relentless force who carved through the defense with an artist’s precision. Each swish of the net was another stanza in his masterpiece, leaving the Detroit defenders grasping at air and the home crowd in stunned silence.

While Rice’s brilliance illuminated the offensive end, the Hornets’ victory was sealed with defensive resolve in the final quarter. Vlade Divac, the team's cerebral center, anchored the paint with 7 crucial blocks, turning the key into a no-fly zone as the Pistons mounted a desperate comeback. His presence allowed Rice to focus on his historic scoring spree without the pressure of a tight contest.

In the end, the final score was a mere footnote. The real story was written in the scoring column next to Rice’s name: 47. On this night, in a hostile arena, one superstar transcended the game, delivering a performance that would be etched into franchise lore and remembered as one of the most explosive individual showcases of the 1990s.
